  • Description: DMP WAS CALLED FOR A SPILL AT THE END OF THE NIGHT. DMP WENT TO THE SPILL WITH A FULLY STOCKED SPILL CART, ALL APPROPRIATE PPE ON, AND CREATED A 15FT HOTZONE. THE DECISION TREE WAS USED. THE INITAL READING WAS OUT OF THE 6-9 RANGE. AFTER NEUTRALIZING THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED AND RETURNED TO DMP FOR PROCESSING

item.title: Report X-2024030444
item.description:
Report X-2024030444

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-19T15:11:49+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-06
  • City: ROCK ISLAND
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: While unloading trailer 557169 from SCHG the haz mat was discovered wet and had leaked onto another haz mat package. Both haz mats were put in totes and taking to the Haz Mat cage for inspection. DescribePack: Found a crack on the damaged bottle. On the inside of the handle the seam is cracked about an inch or more. Hard to see the crack initially. The outer package was so damaged from the leak that the top half of the box was gone. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: There was no more leaking once package was found. Cleaned up any mess leftover and put all bottles upright in totes and put in hazmat cage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: SequenceEvent: PKG REMOVED FROM TRAILER AND LOADED TO TUGGER TO TRANSPORT TO LINE. ONCE ON LINE PKG HANDLER WENT TO LOAD TO VAN AND SOME OF CONTENTS DRIPPED ON SHOE. PKG HANDLER STATED THAT THE CONTENTS WAS CAUSING A BURNING SENSATION. PKG HANDLER TRANSPORTED TO RESTROOM TO WASH INFECTED AREA. INCIDENT REPORT FILED AND PKG HANDLER SENT HOME. DescribePack: THERE WERE NO DAMAGE TO OUTSIDE OF PKG. UPON INSPECTION QA NOTICE THAT THE CONTENTS CAPS WERE ALL LOOSE. ONE OF THE CAPS WAS ACTUALLY OFF ONE BOTTLE. INNER PKG SHOWED SOME CONTENTS WERE SPILLED IN TRANSIT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: NA

  • Description: On March 4th a pallet of thirty five gallon drums was damaged by a forklift. One of the drums was punctured allowing all of the liquid to leak out. The drum contained UN3082 Environmentally Hazardous Substance, liquid, n.o.s.(), 9, PGIII. The spill was cleaned up and the drum was placed into a steel salvage drum. An amended shippers dec has been requested.

item.title: Report X-2024030331
item.description:
Report X-2024030331

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-19T15:11:49+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-05
  • City: KEASBEY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2024030331 SequenceEvent: DURING THE OVERNIGHT SORT THE PACKAGE ARRIVED AT THE HAZMAT CAGE SHOWING OBVIOUS SIGNS OF INTERNAL LEAKAGE. UPON INSPECTION ONE BOTTLE OF ZEP MORADO SUPER CLEANER WAS FOUND TO LEAKING. IT HAS APPOROXIMATELY 15% OF LEAKAGE. THE REMAINING CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A SALVAGE DRUM TO BE RETURN TO THE SHIPPER UNLESS OTHERWISE. DescribePack: FAILURE OF ZEP MORADO SUPER CLEANER CAUSED FROM THE PACKAGE BEING DROPPED OR MISHANDLED. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A LINED SALVAGE DRUM TO AWAIT DISPOSITION. 2. X-2024030332 SequenceEvent: DURING THE OVERNIGHT SORT THE PACKAGE ARRIVED AT THE HAZMAT CAGE SHOWING OBVIOUS SIGNS OF INTERNAL LEAKAGE. UPON INSPECTION TWO BOTTLES OF ZEP INDUSTRIAL PURPLE DEGREASER WAS FOUND TO BE MISSING AND ONE SLIGHTLY LEAKING. THE REMAINING CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A SALVAGE DRUM TO BE RETURNED TO SHIPPER UNLESS OTHERWISE. DescribePack: FAILURE OF ZEP INDUSTRIAL PURPLE DEGREASER CAUSED FROM THE PACKAGE BEING DROPPED OR MISHANDLED. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A LINED SALVAGE DRUM TO AWAIT DISPOSITION.

item.title: Report X-2024030531

item.description:

  • City: HAGERSTOWN
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the 150-gallon poly tote and the contractor was unable to determine the volume of material released due to a forklift puncture of one (1) 150-gallon poly tote. Hepaco personnel stated that they believed that some of the released material evaporated. Hepaco personnel transferred the remaining material into a new poly tote and generated one (1) 55-gallon poly drum containing the cut-up poly tote, impacted absorbents and PPE. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024030251
item.description:
Report E-2024030251

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-18T15:10:48+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-08
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Environmental Works was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 40ft-by-20ft area of the concrete terminal floor and estimated that one hundred and fifty (150) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging one (1) poly tote. Environmental Works personnel deployed a neutralizer and then a granular absorbent to the impacted area. The remaining material was transferred to a new poly tote. The spent material was recovered and placed into three (3) 30-gallon poly drums, one (1) 55-gallon metal drum and one (1) 55-gallon poly drum along with the cut-up damaged poly tote. Environmental Works personnel then pressure washed the impacted area and collected the impacted water and containerized the recovered material into one (1) 330-gallon poly tote. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

Hepaco personnel stated that the released material evaporated, and the contractor could not confirm the size of the impacted area and examined the ball valve and determined that there was no damage, just not properly tightened. The ball valve was tightened, and the cargo was shipped on to the consignee. No waste was generated from this response.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-18T15:10:48+00:00

  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A FULLY LABELED HAZMAT PACKAGE THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING WAS DISCOVERED BY AN UNLOADER IN THE TRAILER IN THE UNLOAD. THE UNLOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. WITHIN 5 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE CORRECT PPE. USING THE DECISION TREE AND APPORPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON ONE OF THE INNER 3.8 LITER PLASTIC CONTAINERS WAS LOOSE BY 1/4 OF A TURN AND 2 OUNCES OF LIQUID HAD LEAKED OUT ONTO THE OUTER CARTON.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UAD experienced a UN1823 Caustic Soda Micropearls release from (2) 50-pound paper bags. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 8-ounces of material released to a 7’ x 6’ area of the wooden trailer floor due to improper loading. The damaged bags were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The recovered product, impacted shrink wrap, cardboard, and PPE were collected and containerized into a second 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-06
  • City: EDINBURGH
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 6, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of corrosive liquid was damaged by a faulty skid and released approximately one (1) quart of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Indiana Spill Response (ISR) to remediate the impacted site. ISR personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon overpack that was labeled as salvaged material for further handling by R+L. Crews swept in soda ash, then collected the neutralized product with hand tools. ISR personnel wiped down the dock floor with absorbent pads and cleaners. One (1) 55-gallon drum of neutralized product, PPE, and any cleanup debris was staged onsite for disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: On March 6, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3082 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior, pallets, nearby freight and loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services, Inc. (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel overpacked the damaged 55-gallon drum in one (1) 85-gallon drum. The crew then deployed absorbents to the release and worked them in with hand tools. All impacted absorbents were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum. Both drums were staged onsite for disposal.

  • Description: A STEEL DRUM AIR PACKAGE FROM USA TO CANADA WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY. THE PACKAGE WAS MARKED AND LABELED AS UN1866, RESIN SOLUTION WITH A CLASS 3 DIAMOND LABEL AND SHIPPERS DECLARATION. THE PACKAGE HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY. UPON INSPECTION OF THE STEEL DRUM, THE SIDE IS DENTED AND THE HANDLE IS PUNCTURED CAUSING PRODUCT LEAKING FROM THE PUNCTURED HANDLE.

  • Description: On March 7, 2024, one (1) defective 275-gallon tote of UN1760 leaked approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior during transit. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the release and worked them in with hand tools. A forklift was utilized to perform a gravity transfer of the remaining product from the damaged 275-gallon tote into one (1) new 275-gallon tote. Additional granular absorbents were deployed to the trailer floor to remove any remaining material and worked in with hand tools. All UN1760-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: On March 6, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1719 was crushed in transit due to lack of dunnage and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel collected the damaged pail for disposal. The crew deployed Portland cement to the trailer interior and restacked the undamaged freight for further shipment. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • City: NORTH LITTLE ROCK
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Car was observed during a shove to the hump with ice on the protective housing and vapor visible. Upon inspection, the A end liquid valve was encapsulated in ice and the plug was laying on the pressure plate unsecured and the valve was partially open. The valve was closed, and the odor dissipated. The ice was melted with water, the valve inspected, and no issue found. The plug was properly secured and after a few minutes the valve was checked with snoop and no issues or releases were found. No other issues were found, and the housing was secured with a seal and released back into transportation.

  • Description: RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT PERSON DIRECTED THIS DESIGNATED RESPONDER TO RETRIEVE A WET PACKAGE FROM DOOR 24. RESPONDER RETRIEVED PACKAGE AND DETERMINED THE PACKAGE WAS COMPROMISED DUE TO RAINWATER. AFTER VERIFYING THE CONTENTS OF COMPROMISED PACKAGE, RESPONDER SAW THAT THE INNER PACKAGING HAD A LIMITED QUANTITY DIAMOND LABEL ON EACH BOX. CHECKED THE OUTSIDE OF THE ORIGINAL BOX AND DID NOT FIND ANY DECLARATION OF A HAZARDOUS MATERIAL. ADVISED RMP. RMP CONTACTED THE HAZARDOUS MATERIALS SERVICE CENTER. AFTER SPEAKING WITH HMSC, DIRECTED TO INPUT THE PACKAGE AS A POSSIBLE UNDECLARED INTO THE ELECTRONIC TRACKING AND TRACING SYSTEM.

UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED THE PACKAGE WAS WET DUE TO BAGS OF ICE INSIDE THE BOX THAT HAD MELTED COMPROMISING THE INTEGRITY OF THE BOX. THE REGULAR ICE WAS COOLING 24 X 13 OUNCE AEROSOLS CANS OF FAVORITE DAY WHIPPED DAIRY TOPPING. THE CAN INDICATES THE CONTENTS ARE UNDER PRESSURE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX.

item.title: Report X-2024030242
item.description:
Report X-2024030242

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-14T18:15:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-02
  • City: NEWVILLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: We were called to trailer#822984 in the unload upon it being opened, for a presumed leaking hazmat. When we arrived, we found the hazmat loaded into the trailer upside down and above waist height, it was spilling all over the packages below it and spilled into the belly of the pup as well. All trk #'s above are pkgs that were damaged by this spill, they will be held until I get the disposition back for this incident. Hazmat spill protocol was followed, and all items are stored in Haz cage, spill was cleaned up and ph9'd cleanup supplies are in cage with damaged hazmat as well. Hazmat itself was placed in a hazardous materials tote lined with a bag and is on the corrosive pallet in the Haz cage. DescribePack: The pkg being upside down when loaded more than likely ruined the seal on the bucket. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Cleaned up and followed Haz spill protocol.

item.title: Report E-2024030194
item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-05
  • City: ARLINGTON
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On March 5, 2024, one (!) 5-gallon pail of UN2922 was cracked during loading and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Mid-South Environmental Services (MSES) to remediate the impacted site. MSES personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and sodium bicarbonate to remediate the UN2922-impacted trailer floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and staged on site for transport and disposal.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal ULX experienced a UN1727 Ammonium Biflouride release from a 50-pound poly bag. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 pound of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the wooden trailer floor due to improper loading. The damaged bag and released material were collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The remaining bags were re-stacked and secured for shipment on. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report X-2024030231

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-14T18:15:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-01
  • City: ROANOKE
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: When the contents were discovered being coded for a refusal at the station for being damaged, we discovered that the contents (Which were 2 2.5-gallon jugs of liquid machine detergent which was a hazmat under UN 1760 Corrosive liquids N.O.S. Technical name Sodium Hydroxide) have leaked a small amount of the contents out of the package. Some of the box is wet due on the exterior but that is rain that has soaked a portion of the packaging. Upon closure inspection the caps were loose, and the corrosive liquids were observed to originate at the affected area. None of the liquid contents from inside of the package has been released out of the box, but still leaked from the inner jugs. No inner packing was found inside of the package. DescribePack: The Jugs were observed to have no leaks upon discovery, but some of the liquid inside of the container was out of the container and was at the time of discovery staining the inner exterior box. The caps enclosing the jugs containing the corrosive solution were observed to be loose with the most recently escaped liquid appearing right below the cap. The caps on the containers were promptly tightened and no leaks were observed after test and observing for a leak. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: Upon awareness of the damaged hazmat, the caps were tightened prevent any further leaks.

LSH repalletized the undamaged freight for continued shipping.

item.title: Report X-2024021644
item.description:
Report X-2024021644

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-18T15:10:48+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-02
  • City: DULUTH
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wisconsin Central Railroad Ltd.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: CN Transportation employee observed liquid coming from the top of tank car TILX 726166 while performing switching operations at the CN Proctor yard, Duluth, MN. The employee notified the employee in charge who then notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team and CN Environment to investigate. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location and found (2) of the (6) manway cover swing bolts to be loose (could turn by hand) preventing a proper seal of the gasket allowing the contents to leak out when the car moved. Both the liquid and vapor line vale securement plugs were found tool tight. The shipper security seals were found to be intact at the time of inspection. The security seals were removed from the manway cover and the protective housing cover. The manway cover was opened to inspect the gasket which was found to be in good condition. The manway cover was closed, and all swing bolts were properly tightened. The valve securement plugs were inspected and found tool tight. New security seals were applied. The exterior of the tank car was cleaned off utilizing a degreaser and rags.

  • Description: On2/9/2024 at approximately 1730, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 4009660 at the station location in Jamaica, NY, reporting a corrosive spill. The shipment consists of 3 fiberboard boxes, each marked as "Excepted Quaniities" and each containing a cylinder. One of the boxes leaked during transport. Further inspection revealed that the closure appeared bent, resulting in spillage. Upon obtaining the UN classification of the Hazard class 8 substance from the shipper, it was determined that the commodity may have exceeded the maximum allowable amount for excepted quantities, according to IATA Regulations. An estimated 4000 mL of liquid was discovered in each cylinder. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 2/6/2024 at approximately 1830, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 4346935 is the station location in Hampton, reporting an undeclared dangerous goods shipment. The package consisted of one fiberboard box, containing an inner fiberboard box with a glass bottle inside. The attached paperwork identifies the commodity as "Hydrogen Sulfide", prompting the opening of the shipment for verification. The package was not prepared with the required DG markings, labeling, or paperwork, in accordance with IATA regulations and is being held, pending an FAA investigation. UPDATE: Further review revealed a misclassification of the commodity. The commodity appears to be identified as "fuel oil" and as requesting that test be conducted using "hydrogen sulfide". The spill incident is being resubmitted with the updated classification.

The shipment consisted of two cans classified as "paint" (according to the marking) packaged in dry ice. During inspection, the shipment built up frost on the outer packaging. Further investigation revealed that the package polystyrene lining was damaged, resulting in the condesation buildup. Additionally, one of the cans spilled due to an apparent damaged closure. The outer package does not appear to have UN Specification marking. The shipment has been rejected and is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-2ft area of the terminal floor and estimated that half a gallon of material was released due to damage to the 330-gallon metal tote. Hepaco personnel stated that granular absorbents were deployed prior to their arrival by ESTES terminal personnel and Hepaco deployed additional granular absorbents along with chemical boom. No waste was generated from this response. A 330-gallon metal tote was ordered and Hepaco returned to the site to transfer the remaining from the damaged tote. The impacted absorbents were recovered and containerized into one 15-gallon metal drum along with the spent PPE. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: On 2/20/24, at 1316 hours, personnel in the CSXT Radnor Yard discovered TILX270130, a loaded tank car of Hexamethylenediamine, leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and shipper, Ascend Performance Materials, were notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-02-20-00151). Marion Environmental Inc., a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found 4 of the 4 liquid valve mounting flange bolts were less than tool tight. MEI personnel tightened the flange bolts to secure the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Tara Gardner, tgardn@ascendmaterials.com, 256-552-2528). The car was held at Radnor pending further repair and qualification by certified repair unit.

  • Description: Hepaco was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 3ft-by-3ft area of the concrete floor and estimated that two (2) pints of material was released due to puncture of one (1) 330- gallon poly tote. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area. The contractor transferred the remaining material into a new poly tote. The damaged poly tote and spent absorbents were containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The new poly tote and generated drums of waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Truck and trailer with hazardous waste load on a van trailer were in route. This load contained metal drums of waste flammable liquid. Driver stopped to take a break at a rest area in KY and discovered that there was a leak coming from the rear of the trailer. Local Fire Dept and Police were dispatched to the scene. An emergency response company was also retained and dispatched to the scene for response and clean up. For precaution the Fire Department evacuated the rest area. Upon investigation it was determined that one of the metal drums had been punctured and had leaked out inside the trailer and them some had leaked from the rear of the trailer onto the ground. The trailer was unloaded and decontaminated and the punctured drum was placed in an overpack and loaded back onto the trailer along with the other drums. The response crew also cleaned up the small amount that reached the ground. All waste was placed back on the trailer and transported to destination.

item.title: Report X-2024030578
item.description:
Report X-2024030578

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-15T15:11:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-25
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CN RAILROAD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On Sunday, Febuary 25, 2024, a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be leaking from tank car # GBRX 703408 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Transportation Manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location for mitigation. The contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap. It was determined that there was a failure in the sealing surface of the valve seat to include a defective gasket. (The BOV cap was found to be tool tight and the BOV in the closed position and pinned upon initial inspection). CN emergency response contractor did observe cable seal to be correctly in place. The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. It was noted that the BOV cap gasket was deformed and was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, CN emergency response contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

This caused a spill at the bottom of the fiberboard box. The spilled contents stayed within the box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Management team placed clear bags and absorbent pads around the leaking package.   • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Post-incident inspection revealed a malfunctioning vapor recovery system on the 87E10 storage tank at the delivery location. The spill was the result of the delivery driver improperly disconnecting the delivery coupling while the system was pressurized. The pressure equalized after 4-5 minutes and the overfill subsided. Local EMS responded as did a professional response team to mitigate the effects of the release. The released gasoline entered the stormwater retention basin at the delivery site and just into the outflow area on the property. The spill did not leave the premises. No surface water or ground water was impacted.

  • Description: X-2024030161: SequenceEvent: Wet fiberboard box found with Class 8 label, fully regulated markings and paperwork in lined red tote on HMPA staging pallet. Ftrack shows OVH scan at NASH on 2/24/24, 16:14. Spidr shows potential damage as early as 2/24, 15:08. NO UNPOP RATING FOUND ON INNER CONTAINERS DESPITE "OVERPACK" LABEL FOUND ON OUTER PACKAGING. HAZMAT PACKAGE IS NON-COMPLIANT AND DID NOT RECEIVE A 97 (HAP FAILURE) AT ORIGIN ELOU. PLEASE NOTE THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN ENTERED AS UNPROCESSED AT DISCOVERY FACILITY NASH. PLEASE ADVISE IF 49 CFR 178.3(a)(1) AND 49 CFR 178.503(a) AND 49 CFR 178.503(f) NO LONGER APPLY. DescribePack: One of four 1 gallon plastic bottles lost 0.7 gallon of fluid due to a loose cap closure, inadequate preparation for transport, and potential mishandling (see above). It should be noted every safety seal was attached to the underside of the cap closure and had no hold on the mouth of the bottle. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: PPE donned, ventilation used. PLEASE NOTE THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN ENTERED AS UNPROCESSED AT DISCOVERY FACILITY NASH. PLEASE ADVISE IF 49 CFR 178.3(a)(1) AND 49 CFR 178.503(a) AND 49 CFR 178.503(f) NO LONGER APPLY.   • Description: SequenceEvent: The Damaged Hazmat came down the sorter onto the flex. The package was discovered to be wet from the side of the package. The package was then placed into a red bin and Hazmat bag to be properly worked on. DescribePack: The package when discovered had a wet spot on the side of the box about 3 inches in length. Upon opening the package, it was viewed to be caused by a loose cap on one of the bottles of Zep Liquid heat. The loose cap leaked out liquid onto itself, another bottle, and the box. The loose cap had loose play to it compared to the others which had a tightly placed cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was placed in a red bin and hazmat bag in case any of its contents continued to leak. The package was also placed up in accordance with its load arrows to prevent any more spillage.

Manager Placed package inside a hazmat bag with absorbent, and informed QA Admin. QA Admin came with hazmat tote and placed hazmat bag with leaky package and absorbent inside the tote. DescribePack: The top cap of two bottles came loose and caused liquid to leak out. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Wet Package was placed inside a hazmat bag with absorbent.

item.title: Report E-2024030182
item.description:
Report E-2024030182

  • City: LAREDO

  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 5, 2024 at 1213 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Laredo, Texas regarding the release of approximately (2) gallons KEROPUR AP 205-20, UN1307 3, III from (1) 55-gallon DM. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release was caused by a puncture from a nail and was contained to a small area on the trailer floor and a 2’ x 2’ area of asphalt beneath the trailer. Contractors were able to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. The damaged drum with product was placed in an 85-gallon overpack DM. All waste generated from addressing this release, was containerized in (1) 5-gallon poly drum, and (1) 85-gallon overpack DM, which was then staged onsite by the contractors for proper disposal.

  • Description: On February 29, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of Xylene (UN1307) was damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Indiana Spill Response (ISR) to remediate the impacted site. ISR personnel deployed granular absorbents to the xylene-impacted trailer and pavement and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. ISR personnel transferred the product from the damaged 275-gallon tote into a new one. All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: On February 29, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon jug of UN1789 was crushed in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior, tires, and asphalt parking lot. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the impacted site. The damaged drum was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. PES crews utilized a neutralizing solution and absorbent pads on the impacted trailer and tires. The deployed granular absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum. Crews deployed a neutralizing solution onto the impacted asphalt and worked them in with hand tools. All UN1789-impacted material was collected and containerized into the previously generated 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024030016
item.description:
Report I-2024030016

Identified by scraper @ 2024-03-14T18:15:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-30
  • City: Willoughby
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: STG LOGISTICS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. Leak was discovered coming from intermodal container (trailer), while staged at facility. Area was isolated and Willoughby Fire Department was dispatched to assess the site. Willoughby FD applied absorbent pads to the affected asphalt lot and deployed absorbent boom to nearby storm drains. Clean Harbors Environmental Services was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, Clean Harbors Environmental applied additional absorbent material to the affected asphalt, inspected the nearby storm drain catch basins, and inspected the Ieaking trailer. Upon inspection, one 275gallon tote was discovered punctured at nose of trailer. Approximately 170 gallons of free product were released to the trailer floor, asphalt lot, and nearby storm drain catch basins. Clean Harbors Environmental proceeded to pH the impacted storm drains, which were returned neutral. Clean Harbors Environmental cleaned the trailer floor, wiped down adjacent freight, recovered spent absorbent material from the impacted asphalt, and emptied damaged tote. Two 55-gallon drums of free product, and 10 55-gallon drums of spent absorbent material and deanup debris were generated during the cleanup. Product was contained to an impervious surface and did not impact surface soils or state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.
